body: Do you have permissions to create `/workspace`? Please try `os.mkdir('/workspace')`. If it fails with the same error, this is not an MLflow issue.

@harupy  I did not pick `/workspace` as destination (presumably for artifacts since the Artifact URI is `file:///workspace/mlruns/0/5b986cb300594fe2b2730742acf6953a/artifacts` as reported above). Indeed, user has no permissions to write to `/workspace` or to create `/workspace` (would likely require superuser access to write to the FS root directory), but it is unclear why this error happens only when another run has started and was terminated before completing. So I would still consider it an issue with the defaults of MLflow, or at least (admitting that it is not a bug), a question -- how does one specify artifact URI destinations different than the default reported above?

> I did not pick /workspace as destination

Can you open `/home/local/dev/mlruns/0/meta.yaml` and what the value of `artifact_location` is?

> how does one specify artifact URI destinations different than the default reported above?

To use a different artifact URI, you need to create a new experiment with `mlflow.create_experiment` ([doc](https://www.mlflow.org/docs/latest/python_api/mlflow.html#mlflow.create_experiment)).

@harupy thanks for your prompt feedback.
Sure:
```yaml
artifact_location: file:///workspace/mlruns/0
experiment_id: '0'
lifecycle_stage: active
name: Default
```

However I normally run my code under a second experiment
```yaml
artifact_location: file:///workspace/mlruns/1
experiment_id: '1'
lifecycle_stage: active
name: CannotDisclose
```

Perhaps I am missing out on what the proper way of having multiple runs on the same experiment is?

I set the experiment explicitly in my training script:
```python
    # MLFlow Logging
    mlflow.set_experiment("CannotDisclose")
    with mlflow.start_run(run_name=f"{model_type}-{tstamp}-{config_md5}"):
         # ...
```

Note that other than this quirk I am able to use the Tracking API without issues, view multiple runs, inspect the artifacts, etc.
I only have this issue with accessing `/workspace` when the last run didn't terminate properly.

@VC86 

```python
with mlflow.start_run():
    assert mlflow.get_artifact_ur().startswith("file:///workspace/mlruns")
    mlflow.log_artifact(__file__)
```

Does this code run successfully?

Nope, this:

```python
import mlflow

with mlflow.start_run():
    assert mlflow.get_artifact_uri().startswith("file:///workspace/mlruns")
    mlflow.log_artifact(__file__)
```

in the above described configuration (Ubuntu22.04 LTS, py39) yields:

```python
/home/localuser/mambaforge3/envs/tf_dev/bin/python /home/localuser/pycharm-community-2022.1.3/plugins/python-ce/helpers/pydev/pydevd.py --multiprocess --qt-support=auto --client 127.0.0.1 --port 34405 --file /home/localuser/dev/test.py
Connected to pydev debugger (build 221.5921.27)

  File "/home/localuser/mambaforge3/envs/tf_dev/lib/python3.9/site-packages/mlflow/tracking/client.py", line 955, in log_artifact

  File "/home/localuser/mambaforge3/envs/tf_dev/lib/python3.9/site-packages/mlflow/tracking/_tracking_service/client.py", line 365, in log_artifact
    artifact_repo.log_artifact(local_path, artifact_path)
  File "/home/localuser/mambaforge3/envs/tf_dev/lib/python3.9/site-packages/mlflow/store/artifact/local_artifact_repo.py", line 37, in log_artifact
```

@VC86 I have four questions.

1. Are you sure this issue occurs only when the last run didn't terminate properly? Did you run the code I shared after the last run terminated properly or not?

2. Does your code log artifacts?

3. Does `/workspace/mlruns` exist?
 
4. Is there a reason you need to use `/workspace`? Why not use `/home/local/dev`?

@harupy thanks again for the follow-up, much appreciated
1. Yes, I am sure. I reran the minimal example you provided and indeed, if the run terminates properly the assertion fails. This is because the artifact URI (when, e.g., deleting the `mlruns/` folder in the current directory and "starting from scratch") is then `file:///home/localuser/dev/mlruns/0/b59819c7deb14880b7168f91f857f224/artifacts` for example, instead of `file:///workspace/mlruns/0/ea5634b7b072420f89415601b091189d/artifacts` which happens when the previous run was not correctly terminated.
2. Yes, I log dictionaries, more generic artifacts (custom images, json files, h5 files, ...)
3. No, it does not in general and the local user has (correctly) no clearance to write to `/workspace/` (as it has no permission to write to `/` since that would presumably come with admin rights...)
4. I don't need to use `/workspace` but as I specified earlier -- I am not setting it anywhere explicitly! This is somehow set automatically as default, I don't actively/knowingly/intentionally set this anywhere! My `mlruns/` folder is normally in the directory where I launch my training script -- where I have all rights I need. But somehow in some pathological cases MLflow is trying to write to `/workspace`...

> This is because the artifact URI (when, e.g., deleting the mlruns/ folder in the current directory and "starting from scratch") is then file:///home/localuser/dev/mlruns/0/b59819c7deb14880b7168f91f857f224/artifacts for example, instead of file:///workspace/mlruns/0/ea5634b7b072420f89415601b091189d/artifacts which happens when the previous run was not correctly terminated.

This is strange. I have no clue why this happens. Can you share the full code you use with sensitive information masked or create a script that can reproduce this behavior?

I also faced the same issue with `/workspace`. For some reason this location just refuses to work. My setup involved docker. The solution for me was to use `/opt/workspace/` or literally any other workspace location. However it seems to me that your error is that `workspace` is not created by you, therefore can you print your `env` and show us the contents?
@thethiny thanks, can I ask you how do you set your `/workspace` to `/opt/workspace/`? This is not yet clear to me...

@harupy I will try, unfortunately the script is full of confidential information. I tried to create one minimal working example with your code snippet. It shows the error but only after the other script has failed to terminate properly (i.e., I halt execution in PyCharm).
